events.originalText: Nine bombs placed by the Indian Mujahideen, then an unknown terrorist group, exploded in a 15-minute period in Jaipur, India, killing 80 people and injuring more than 200 others.
events.subtitle: Indian Mujahideen
events.headline: Indian Mujahideen bombs kill 80 in Jaipur, India

events.originalText: Uzbek Interior Ministry and State Security Service troops fired at protesters in Andijan, killing between 187 and 1,500 people.
events.subtitle: Ministry of Internal Affairs (Uzbekistan)
events.headline: Troops fire at protesters in Andijan, Uzbekistan

events.originalText: An explosion (aftermath pictured) at a fireworks factory in Enschede, Netherlands, resulted in 23 deaths and approximately €450 million in damage.
events.subtitle: Enschede fireworks disaster
events.headline: Explosion at fireworks factory in Enschede, Netherlands kills 23

events.originalText: Li Hongzhi introduced the Falun Gong movement at a public lecture in Changchun, China.
events.subtitle: Li Hongzhi
events.headline: Falun Gong movement introduced in Changchun, China

events.originalText: Eleven members of the American black liberation group MOVE were killed when a Philadelphia police helicopter dropped a bomb on their house during a raid.
events.subtitle: Black theology
events.headline: 11 MOVE members killed in Philadelphia police raid

events.originalText: The Troubles: A car bomb planted by Ulster loyalists exploded outside a crowded pub in Belfast, Northern Ireland, beginning two days of gun battles between the British Army, the Provisional Irish Republican Army, and the Ulster Volunteer Force.
events.subtitle: The Troubles
events.headline: Car bomb in Belfast triggers gun battles

events.originalText: Sino-Malay race riots began in Kuala Lumpur, leaving at least 190 people dead, with the government declaring a state of emergency and suspending the Parliament of Malaysia until 1971.
events.subtitle: 13 May incident
events.headline: Sino-Malay race riots leave 190 dead in Kuala Lumpur

events.originalText: The Australian adventurer Ben Carlin became the only person to circumnavigate the world in an amphibious vehicle, having travelled over 80,000 kilometres (50,000 miles) by land and sea.
events.subtitle: Ben Carlin
events.headline: Ben Carlin circumnavigates the world in amphibious vehicle

events.originalText: US vice president Richard Nixon's motorcade was attacked by a mob in Caracas, Venezuela.
events.subtitle: Richard Nixon
events.headline: Richard Nixon's motorcade attacked in Caracas, Venezuela

events.originalText: The Russian inventor Igor Sikorsky flew the self-designed Russky Vityaz, the world's first four-engine fixed-wing aircraft.
events.subtitle: Igor Sikorsky
events.headline: Igor Sikorsky flies world's first four-engine fixed-wing aircraft

events.originalText: The first edition of the Giro d'Italia, a long-distance multiple-stage bicycle race, began in Milan; the Italian  cyclist Luigi Ganna was the eventual winner.
events.subtitle: 1909 Giro d'Italia
events.headline: First Giro d'Italia race begins in Milan

events.originalText: The Australian astronomer John Tebbutt discovered the Great Comet of 1861, through the tail of which the Earth passed later that year.
events.subtitle: John Tebbutt
events.headline: Astronomer John Tebbutt discovers Great Comet of 1861

events.originalText: The English mystic Julian of Norwich recovered from a severe illness during which she experienced a series of intense visions of Christ, which she later described in the first known English-language book written by a woman.
events.subtitle: Mysticism
events.headline: Julian of Norwich recovers from illness with visions of Christ
